<summary>
The present invention relates to a cooled flow deflection apparatus for thermal machines, specifically for high-temperature fluid-flow machines. The invention aims to address the disadvantages of prior art flow deflection apparatuses, such as complex casting, high blade weight, and difficulty in cooling the transitional region between the hot-gas wall and the separating wall. The solution is to construct the separating walls as separate inserts that are subsequently inserted into the apparatus and secured. This results in simplified production, flexible matching to applications, and efficient cooling. A preferred embodiment involves a hollow casting with integrally formed holders for the separating walls, which simplifies assembly and attachment. Another embodiment involves connecting the inserted separating walls by an integral material joint for added security. The cooling fluid can flow in mutually opposite directions in adjacent cooling channels, and the deflection is produced by a bent separating wall. The invention can be applied to various types of blades, including rotor blades in gas turbines.
</summary>

The present invention pertains to a cooled flow deflection apparatus for thermal machines, particularly for high-temperature fluid-flow machines. The invention aims to overcome the disadvantages of prior art flow deflection apparatuses, such as complex casting, high blade weight, and difficulty in cooling the transitional region between the hot-gas wall and the separating wall. The solution is to construct the separating walls as separate inserts that are subsequently inserted into the apparatus and secured. This results in simplified production, flexible matching to applications, and efficient cooling.

A preferred embodiment involves a hollow casting with integrally formed holders for the separating walls, which simplifies assembly and attachment. The separating walls are flat strips composed of metallic or heat-resistant non-metallic materials. Another embodiment involves connecting the inserted separating walls by an integral material joint, such as soldering or welding, for added security.

The cooling fluid can flow in mutually opposite directions in adjacent cooling channels, and the deflection is produced by a bent separating wall. The invention can be applied to various types of blades, including rotor blades in gas turbines.

The separating walls are not cast with the blade but are separate inserts that are introduced through the blade root or blade tip. Holders in the form of rails are integrally

<summary>
The present invention relates to an air intake device for an internal combustion engine that improves performance and reduces noise. It includes a tank, two pipes with different cross-sectional areas, and a control valve. The tank is extended along the intake pipe, and the two pipes interconnect the tank and intake pipe at different locations. The larger pipe opens to the intake passage farther from the air cleaner, while the smaller pipe opens closer to it. A vacuum diaphragm actuator opens the control valve in response to engine load. The smaller pipe's smaller cross-sectional area creates a resonator that absorbs intake noise, reducing it to an acceptable level. The valve's operation improves engine performance by creating a new compound curve from the volumetric efficiency curves when the valve is open and closed. The length of the air inlet pipe upstream of the air cleaner is decreased to improve performance but increases noise, so the present invention aims to decrease noise while maintaining performance.
</summary>

<summary>
The invention relates to a two-part bracket system for mounting speakers or other equipment on various surfaces, including poles, walls, and columns. The system consists of a stationary bracket and an adjustable bracket. The adjustable bracket is attached to the object to be mounted and then positioned on the stationary bracket to secure the object. The adjustable bracket can be easily rotated into a locked position and temporarily snapped into place using integrated hooks and tabs. Two axel screws are inserted to form the hinge and secure the assembly. The adjustable bracket can be rotated to adjust the product's position and dispersion pattern. For pole mounting, the system includes pole clamp assemblies with adapter brackets that fit a wide range of pole sizes and shapes. The assembly is designed for one person to install and is resistant to weather, wind, and vibration.
</summary>

<summary>
The text describes an invention related to a mounting link between an engine and a gearbox, which includes a male link, a female link, and a pin. The female link receives the male link to allow translation and forms a radial interface for dampening translation. The pin selectively retains the male and female links. The radial interface provides coulomb damping to dissipate energy created by translation.
</summary>

The invention relates to a mounting link between an engine and a gearbox, which includes a male link, a female link, and a pin. The female link receives the male link to allow translation and forms a radial interface for dampening translation. The pin selectively retains the male and female links. The radial interface provides coulomb damping to dissipate energy created by translation.

The mounting link includes a female link, a male link, and a pin. The female link receives the male link to allow translation and forms a radial interface for dampening translation. The pin selectively retains the male and female links. The radial interface provides coulomb damping to dissipate energy created by translation.

The text describes a mounting link for an engine and gearbox, consisting of a female link, male link, and pin. The female link receives the male link for translation and forms a radial interface for dampening. The pin selectively retains the links, and the radial interface provides coulomb damping.

<summary>
This document describes an invention related to a waste fuel burner that aims to minimize particulate emissions and operate efficiently. The burner forms a conical pile of waste fuel, which is then gasified and partially oxidized in a primary combustion chamber. Swirl air is introduced tangentially to create a vortex that separates heavier particles from the gas stream. The volatile gases are then partially combusted again in a secondary chamber with secondary air. The flame holder in the secondary chamber prevents particulate matter from entering and forces it back into the primary chamber. The burner is self-regulating and easy to control, with fast response times to changes in load. It can effectively burn wet wood and produce a residue free of clinkers, assuming the ash fusing temperature is not lower than 1700°F. The primary and secondary chambers can be added to any source of dirty, particulate-laden combustible gas to provide heat and meet emission standards.
</summary>

The invention pertains to methods and apparatus for generating heat from waste fuels like wood waste while minimizing particulate emissions. The document describes a waste fuel burner that forms a conical pile of waste fuel and gasifies it using preheated underfire air. Swirl air is introduced tangentially to create a vortex that separates heavier particles from the gas stream. The volatile gases are then partially combusted again in a secondary chamber with secondary air. The flame holder in the secondary chamber prevents particulate matter from entering and forces it back into the primary chamber. The burner is self-regulating and easy to control, with fast response times to changes in load. It can effectively burn wet wood and produce a residue free of clinkers, assuming the ash fusing temperature is not lower than 1700°F. The primary and secondary chambers can be added to any source of dirty, particulate-laden combustible gas to provide heat and meet emission standards.

The burner includes a primary combustion chamber lined with refractory material and a secondary chamber with a refractory lining. Preheated underfire air is directed into the pile of fuel, and high-pressure swirl air is introduced tangentially to create a vortex that separates heavier particles from the gas stream. The volatile gases are then partially combusted again in the secondary chamber with

<summary>
The present invention is an electronically controlled pyrotechnic sound and flash simulator for military weapons training, specifically for the M16 automatic weapon. It utilizes a low-cost plastic expendable housing a metal/oxidizer pyrotechnic in conjunction with an electrical ignition system. The invention produces sound and flash by the electrical ignition of the pyrotechnic in a confined space and venting the combustion through the weapon's ejection port. The electrical control circuit provides for automatic and semiautomatic fire, interfaces with the weapon trigger and bolt, and ensures safety precautions. The bolt interface engages the weapon's bolt, trigger interface detects the weapon trigger squeeze, and oscillator control circuit enables the 500 Hertz oscillator when bolt actuation occurs. The firing counter accumulates the timing pulses, and the firing decoder decodes the count to provide a single pulse to the firing control. The firing control utilizes thirty-one SCRs and sixty-two gate resistors to limit gate current and provide temperature stability. The firing sensor detects the charge firing and sends a signal to the oscillator control circuit to turn off the 500 Hertz oscillator. The MILES interface connects the firing sensor output to the MILES unit associated with the weapon. The small arms firing effect simulator is packaged to resemble the magazine clip of the M16, with a reusable housing, electric control circuitry, and plastic expendable containing pyrotechnic charges.
</summary>

The text describes a problem with in-line spark plug arrangements in rotary engines, which disrupt cooling flow and create vapor films that prevent effective heat transfer. The invention addresses this issue by staggering spark plug bosses with respect to the coolant flow, improving the distribution of coolant velocities around the boss surface and reducing locally high thermal conditions. The staggered arrangement also provides separate paths for vapor release during boiling heat transfer. A preferred embodiment of the invention includes two cylindrically shaped and cast bosses that extend across the passageway at a location adjacent the vertically rising section of the flow, with each boss having a terminal that projects onto a point on the trochoid wall preferably offset from the centerline of the trochoid wall. The bosses are arranged to form angles with respect to the planes dividing the coolant passage longitudinally and transversely, and the cylindrical trunk of each boss has the terminals spaced apart a longitudinal distance that is less than 12 diameters of each boss. The staggered configuration of the spark plug bosses results in high velocity flow through them that is controlled and devoid of uncontrolled swirling eddies, allowing for a high heat transfer coefficient to be maintained at the sensitive spark plug boss surfaces.

<summary>
This document describes a fluid pump with multiple pump heads arranged in series, allowing fluid to flow from a reservoir through each pump head and be discharged out of the final pump head. The pump heads have a housing containing an impeller, a drive shaft, and a housing extension. The impeller is mounted on the drive shaft and draws fluid from the previous pump head through a single inlet. The fluid then flows through curved conduits and is combined into a single flow before exiting the pump head. The pump heads are connected so that the outlet of one combiner is in direct fluid communication with the inlet of the next pump head. The drive shafts are connected by a biconical tubular connector, which prevents fluid from entering the drive train and protects it from corrosion and befouling. The pump can be mounted on various support structures such as a wheeled boom, hitching assembly, or trailer.
</summary>

The document describes a fluid pump with multiple pump heads arranged in series, where fluid flows from a reservoir through each pump head and is eventually discharged out of the final pump head. Each pump head has a housing containing an impeller, a drive shaft, and a housing extension. The impeller is mounted on the drive shaft and draws fluid from the previous pump head through a single inlet. The fluid then flows through curved conduits and is combined into a single flow before exiting the pump head. The pump heads are connected so that the outlet of one combiner is in direct fluid communication with the inlet of the next pump head. The drive shafts are connected by a biconical tubular connector, which prevents fluid from entering the drive train and protects it from corrosion and befouling. The pump can be mounted on various support structures such as a wheeled boom, hitching assembly, or trailer.

The fluid pump consists of two or more pump heads arranged in series, with fluid flowing from a reservoir into one pump head and then into the next pump head in the series, until it is eventually discharged from an outlet in a final pump head. Each pump head comprises a housing within which an impeller is contained, the impeller being driven by the drive structure to move fluid. The housing of the pump head comprises an inlet through which fluid is drawn from outside the housing, and the fluid is moved by the impeller from

<summary>
This text describes an engine compression release brake system for engines with less than all cylinders having engine brakes. Traditional engine compression release brake systems include an engine brake for each cylinder, but this invention reduces the number of components by providing engine brakes for only a portion of the engine cylinders. The engine includes an engine housing defining a plurality of engine cylinders, and an engine compression release brake is provided for each of a portion of the engine cylinders. Each engine compression release brake is operably coupled to a cam actuated exhaust valve. The engine compression release brake system includes a hydraulic system, a high pressure pump, a high pressure manifold, and a hydraulic communication line. The hydraulic system delivers high pressure oil to the engine compression release brakes and returns used oil to a low pressure reservoir. An electronic control module controls multiple aspects of engine operation, including engine compression release brake timing. Each cylinder is operably connected to hydraulically and/or mechanically actuated devices, including a fuel injector and a cam actuated exhaust valve. A portion of cylinders each include a hydraulically actuated engine compression release brake that is operably connected to the exhaust valve for the cylinder. The engine compression release brake includes a solenoid actuator and a spool valve member that is movable between an upward, retracted position and a downward, advanced position. When the solenoid is de-energized, the spool valve member is biased toward its retracted position and fluidly connects actuation fluid passage to a low pressure passage. When the solenoid is energized, the spool valve member moves to its advanced position and blocks actuation fluid passage from the low pressure passage and opens it to the high pressure passage. High pressure fluid acts on the hydraulic surface of the piston in the engine compression release brake, moving it toward its advanced position and causing the exhaust valve actuator to move to an open position for engine braking.
</summary>

The text describes an invention for a cooling fan assembly that eliminates the need for fasteners to secure it to a panel. The fan assembly includes a motor with a housing and mounting legs that fit into recesses in the panel. The legs have resilient portions that compress and expand as the fan is installed, allowing it to be securely held in place without the need for screws or other fasteners. The fan assembly can be used in various applications where forced air cooling is necessary, such as in computer towers. The installation process involves positioning the fan against the panel, applying a compressive and rotating force to compress the spring member and move the fan into place, and allowing the resilient leg portions to spring outwardly and capture in the residual opening in the panel.

The text describes a patent for an improved oil shear type clutch unit for large power transmission requirements in aircraft catapult systems. The clutch unit utilizes separate piston and cylinder means for each set of clutch disc segments and clutch plates, which minimizes residual drag and allows for maximum application of forces. The clutch discs are segmented, allowing for easy replacement without complete disassembly, and the auxiliary fluid pressure control means act as coolants for the clutch discs.

The present invention provides a mixing valve for an aircraft cleaning apparatus with two inlets and one outlet, allowing the mixture to range between 0% inlet A fluid, 100% inlet B fluid to 100% inlet A fluid, 0% inlet B fluid. The valve includes a valve body, two inlet passages, an outlet passage, and a valve means for directing the two fluids toward the outlet passage, which is adjustable to permit the mixture to range between desired proportions.

The valve system includes a valve body with two inlets, a flow restricting device, and an outlet. The flow restricting device reduces the flow rate of fluid from the first inlet, and the size of the second inlet bore reduces the flow rate of water entering the valve. This allows multiple identical valve systems to operate from a common soap solution source and common water source without adversely affecting fluid pressure. The maximum flow rate of fluid occurs only when the bore is axially aligned with its respective fluid communication passages, reducing fluid demand from the respective fluid source and maintaining constant fluid pressures at the inlets.

<summary>
The present disclosure relates to a burner for a heat utilizing appliance that is efficient, clean burning, and can be used with diverse appliances. The burner includes a housing with a fuel holder and a combustion chamber enclosed by an outer wall. Air flows through the fuel holder for initial combustion and around it for secondary combustion. An outer shroud surrounds the upper portion of the housing and channels air inwardly to support secondary combustion and insulate the burner. The burner may have legs for support, a pivotally coupled ash pan, and a perforate food grate. A cover is pivotally coupled to the burner to close the combustion chamber. The burner has manual couplings for removably attaching modular heat utilizing appliances, including cookers, a food smoker, a space heater, and a pyrolyzer.
</summary>

The burner comprises a housing and a fuel holder within it. The housing includes a lateral wall surrounding and spaced apart from the fuel holder, and a top wall with a constricted exhaust outlet above the fuel holder. The lateral and top walls are configured to guide inducted air flowing around the fuel holder inwardly to join exhaust products flowing upwardly through the exhaust outlet, supporting secondary combustion above the fuel holder. The exhaust outlet is constricted to channel products of combustion and secondary and tertiary combustion air towards the exhaust outlet, concentrating heat.

An ash pan is releasably coupled to the burner below the fuel holder and forms a sump to store water for extinguishing burning embers. Air inlet opening opens through the vertical peripheral wall of the ash pan and includes a conduit and a damper for manual throttling of combustion air. In some implementations, the air inlet opening opens through the lateral wall of the housing, and the ash pan is permanently coupled to the housing and movable between a closed and an open position. The ash pan may be pivotally coupled to the housing by a hinge and may be secured in any one of several degrees of inclination to control the amount of combustion air entering the interior of the housing.

The burner may comprise at least one leg for support, whereby it may be supported above a ground surface

The present invention is a method of minimizing steam boiler pressure changes or turbine power changes during turbine control valve operational safety testing by using control valve positions as feedback to minimize flow disturbance. The method involves calculating total mass flow for N parallel flow valves as a function of control valve position and determining the difference in flow characteristics between N and N-1 turbine flow control valves. A test compensation circuit uses this information to compensate for the flow change caused by the closure of one valve during testing. The compensation circuit is reproduced along with the test control circuit and valve servo position loop for each valve. The test compensation array in the circuit provides the required flow compensation for the three input control valves not under test based on the mass flow demanded by the TCV Reference signal. The lift flow array in the circuit translates the stem lift of the tested valve to a total flow demand value for the three input control valves not being tested. The divider circuit in the circuit determines the fraction of flow demand that remains constant during the test closing of a given valve and the varying flow demand for the other three input control valves. The output of the divider circuit is then used to calculate the valve stem lift compensation signal, which is multiplied by the compensation factor to move the lift for the other valves as the tested valve closes. The select circuit in the circuit determines whether the reference signal or the output of the multiplier circuit is fed into the summing circuit, which then calculates the valve lift of the tested valve. The control system containing the algorithms for compensation of flow during valve testing reduced the pressure excursion of the turbine inlet main steam pressure by 95% compared to the control system without flow compensation.

The text describes a problem with spacecraft structures using lightweight composites, which have low damping and can lead to high vibration levels that compromise instrument functionality. Kinematic mounts, used to support precision instruments, have limited success as they provide no provisions to minimize loads transmitted to the instrument. The present invention aims to provide kinematic mounts with novel damping features to protect instruments from potentially damaging flight loads. Two preferred embodiments of the damper design are presented: a spherical damper using viscoelastic material and a cylindrical slot damper using o-rings. Both designs introduce damping into the six mount suspension modes, reducing high energy disturbances to the instrument. The damping mechanism preserves the fundamental features of the kinematic mounts, including strength, stiffness, and kinematic features. The unique frequency-dependent properties of space-qualified viscoelastic material make it a viable candidate for damping kinematic mounts during flight. The invention enables the use of damped kinematic mounts to protect instruments from potentially damaging flight loads, and alternative damped KM design concepts may be used as long as they satisfy the objectives. The design can be simplified by using truss structures or a set of three damped versions of the mount configuration. The mounting scheme can also provide a center-of-gravity mounting system, which is important for instruments with dynamic disturbances.

<summary>
The present invention relates to a method and arrangement for compressing gas in a compressor station for a gas pipeline, particularly in permanent frost areas. The method includes compressing gas to a higher pressure, cooling it, and then expanding it to the desired exit pressure to obtain further cooling. The compressor station includes a compressor, heat exchanger, valve-controlled pipelines, control units, and an electronic control system. The electronic control system compresses the gas to an excess pressure and then expands it to the desired exit pressure. The invention utilizes the physical effect that a compressed gas is cooled when expanded to a lower pressure and provides for cooling by heat exchange and expansion in an expansion turbine. The compressors in the primary compression stages can be completely exchanged for one another, and the compressors used in the stages can be optimized based on the required nominal pressure and environmental conditions. The compressor station can be controlled by an electronic control system, and it is possible to use several compressors in parallel in each primary compression stage. The invention provides for significant cost savings and reduced operation risk compared to conventional re-cooling plants.
</summary>

The present invention is related to a method and arrangement for compressing gas in a compressor station for a gas pipeline, particularly in permanent frost areas. The method includes compressing gas to a higher pressure, cooling it, and then expanding it to the desired exit pressure to obtain further cooling. The compressor station includes a compressor, heat exchanger, valve-controlled pipelines, control units, and an electronic control system. The electronic control system compresses the gas to an excess pressure and then expands it to the desired exit pressure.

The invention utilizes the physical effect that a compressed gas is cooled when expanded to a lower pressure, either by throttling or with the simultaneous performance of work. In order to ensure the required exit pressure or nominal pressure at the exit of the compressor station, the present invention provides that the gas to be transported is compressed to an excess pressure which is substantially above the exit pressure, and then cooled by heat exchange and expanded to the desired exit pressure.

The compressors in the primary compression stages can be completely exchanged for one another, and the compressors used in the stages can be optimized based on the required nominal pressure and environmental conditions. The compressor station can be

The text describes a system for assessing segmentations of patient structures for radiation therapy using electronic files, which are converted into volume models and compared to identify missing or extra volume elements. The system allows for customizable metric methods to evaluate the conformance of the compared segmentation to the standard segmentation and provides an intuitive display for identifying regions of error.

The text describes an engine system that utilizes expansion cylinders downstream of combustion cylinders to expand exhaust gases and create additional drive for a common crankshaft. The system also incorporates water injection and recovery, as well as gearing between cylinders to optimize output. The goal is to reduce the temperature of fluids associated with the engine to eliminate the need for a radiator in a vehicle.

The text describes an invention related to a rolling body guide cage produced from at least one ring element and several guide structures. The ring element is made from flat material ring segments joined and welded together before obtaining axial profiling. This design reduces cutting waste during manufacturing and is particularly advantageous for rolling body guide cages with an internal diameter over 140 mm. The method for manufacturing this cage involves joining flat material ring segments and welding them together before forming the cage. The weld points can be formed using laser welding or pressure welding.

<summary>
The text describes methods and systems for obtaining and processing information related to customer service locations in telecommunications networks. The systems include a technician input device for receiving and transmitting information, a technician server for processing and verifying data, and a global positioning satellite system for obtaining coordinates. The methods involve requesting coordinates from a technician, obtaining coordinates from the GPS system, and updating databases with the coordinates. The systems also include a mapping system for generating directions for travel between customer service locations. The GPS system is used to acquire coordinates for customer service locations and to track technician locations. The dispatch system receives and processes service requests, and the address guide system stores and maintains valid addresses. The customer record system stores customer information and interfaces with the dispatch system to generate work orders. The methods and systems enhance customer service response time and efficiency.
</summary>

The text describes an invention related to data processing systems and the execution of floating point operations. Floating point operations, which involve adding and subtracting numbers represented in the floating point format, can be complex and time-consuming. The invention aims to accelerate the effective subtraction operation by using a difference between a subset of signals in the operand exponent arguments to begin the subtraction of differences between operand fractions. The procedures are chosen such that when the complete operand argument difference is different from the subset operand argument difference, the correct result fraction is one of the operand fractions, which is available. The text also describes two procedures, one for when the absolute value of the difference in the arguments of the exponents is greater than one, and another for when it is less than or equal to one, and illustrates the steps involved in each procedure. The apparatus implementing the procedures includes units for determining the difference between the subset of operand exponent arguments and for selecting the appropriate procedure based on the result.

This invention describes the use of waveguide holograms for controlled illumination of objects, particularly holograms and spatial light modulators. Thin substrate waveguides are used to achieve high diffraction efficiencies and compact, rugged arrangements, while also minimizing stray light and achieving high spectral selectivity. Challenges such as alignment sensitivity, illumination depletion, and two-sidedness are addressed through various solutions.

The text describes a method and system for tracking specimens acquired from patients, reducing mislabeling of specimen vials in hospitals. The method involves generating unique patient and order barcode numbers, storing patient information in a relational database, and ensuring the patient and order barcode numbers are related before storing vial barcode numbers in the same database. The system includes a computer, storage, and electronic reading means for scanning barcodes on patient ID bands, orders, specimen vials, and specimen-taker ID badges. Upon scanning, the processor determines if the patient and order barcode numbers are related and stores the vial barcode number in the database. The system generates signals to acquire specimens and stores indications when they are placed in vials. The system eliminates the need for vial labels and associated printers, providing a failsafe, zero-defect process for identifying and processing patient specimen samples. The invention can be implemented using one or more standalone or networked computers and local or remote computer storage, and can be used for acquiring any type of biological specimen.

The text describes an invention of a voice-activated distance measuring device for golfers, which uses both GPS technology and voice recognition technology. The device can be incorporated into articles of clothing or headgear, such as a golf hat or visor. It provides distance and other golf course information verbally to the user. The device may also memorize and compute user data to predict golf strategy and club selection. The invention uses a bone conductance vibration sensor for clear voice recognition and a Bluetooth connection for data transfer and communication. The device can be used for various applications beyond golfing. The text also mentions the design of the device, including the placement of the circuit board assembly in a hat brim and the use of a rectangular battery and a down-facing speaker.

The text describes a method for investigating samples derived from biological sources using CARS microscopy, which involves furnishing at least one resonance site by means of a bioorthogonal reaction of an intrinsic chemical structure of the sample with at least one further reaction partner. Bioorthogonal reactions are chemical reactions that can proceed in living systems without interfering with natural processes. The invention allows for the selective detection of target sites in samples without negatively affecting biochemical processes and enables an improvement in the reproducibility of CARS methods. The use of bioorthogonal reactions in combination with CARS microscopy allows for the generation of a stable, reproducible background signal, which can be correlated with signals attributable to intrinsic resonance sites of the sample. The invention is particularly advantageous for samples that do not inherently have resonance sites, such as the inherently non-resonant background in conventional methods, which yields statistical signals that are not reproducible. The method can be used in a confocal scanning microscope and involves the use of lasers for generating pump and Stokes light beams, which are focused onto the sample and detected as resonance signals.

The present invention provides a design rule checking system and method for accurately reporting errors for appropriate regions in a system that includes both logic and memory circuits. It eliminates false errors caused by logic rule checks in memory blocks and helps pinpoint real design rule errors in the mask pattern data. Customized design rules are created for different types of memory regions based on modifying standard logic rules to accommodate more liberal memory-based parameter values. The system can be applied to any mask pattern database, including those with no memory blocks or multiple types of memory blocks. Different types of memory are identified in the mask pattern data, and appropriate design rules are applied to each region. The invention ensures that all memory regions fulfill all memory rules of their group, and all logic regions fulfill both logic and memory rules. The process is more reliable, efficient, and avoids false errors compared to prior art techniques.

The present application is a continuation of a previous patent application related to a Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) system for optimally navigating and operating a mobile energy recovery structure in severe weather conditions. The system uses GPS, weather satellite data, and telecommunications satellites for communication and data collection. The mobile structure, which can be a sailing vessel or other energy recovery system, communicates with the central service facility through a wireless system or fiber optic cable. The system includes a control and communications microprocessor system on the mobile structure and a microprocessor system running secure server software applications and workstations with secure client software at the central service facility. The microprocessor system on the mobile structure requires input, output, and I/O functions for communicating with various sensors and control circuits. The system uses SCADA object tag definitions for data communication between the mobile structure, central service facility, and various weather data sources. The system includes control-actuating electromechanical circuits for actuating mechanical members such as rudders, propellers, and sails. The Graphical User Interface (GUI) on the client workstations allows humans to interact with the system and invoke various SCADA algorithms for energy efficiency analysis, points of sail adjustment, and weather pattern analysis.

<summary>
The text describes a method for securing a mobile device by granting access to native resources of the operating system only to approved managed libraries, while denying access to untrusted managed applications. The method involves validating digital certificates associated with managed libraries and managed applications, and using a manager to authorize access to native resources based on the information obtained from these certificates. The manager is effectuated by native instructions and can be configured to identify managed libraries that a managed application is authorized to access. The method also includes receiving a request from a managed application to access a native system resource through a managed library, authorizing the request by the manager, and accessing the native system resource by the runtime host.
</summary>

The text describes an invention that enables the manufacturing of electrically programmable random access memory (EPROM) devices using existing integrated circuit (IC) technologies, specifically for DRAM and logic circuits. The invention utilizes DRAM storage capacitors as coupling capacitors for EPROM devices, allowing for higher gate coupling ratios and reduced operation voltages. The EPROM devices can be used for programmable redundancy circuits on DRAM devices, offering smaller area, higher performance, and the ability to be re-programmed in the field. The invention also introduces stress effect programmable read-only memory (SEPROM) devices, which use the damages caused by electrical stresses on common transistors to store data. SEPROM devices offer advantages such as being manufacturable by any IC technologies, ideal for embedded applications, and providing large storage capacity at low cost. However, they may require longer time to write data and cannot be re-programmed for many cycles.

<summary>
This text describes an improved identification card invention that includes an internal antenna and integrated circuit chip sandwiched between two protective, non-rigid layers, which are then laminated between two rigid outer layers. The invention aims to address the issues of damage to electronic components and complicated production methods in prior art smart cards. The core layer of the card is made of a silica-filled polyolefin and is pre-shrunk to ensure proper printing and attachment of electronic components. An alkyd resin spid containing an anti-binding agent is printed on the core layer, followed by the attachment of antennae and IC chips. The core layer is then bonded to a bottom sheet using an adhesive layer and a carboxylated polyethylene hot melt adhesive. Two transparent polymer layers are affixed to the bonded core layer/bottom layer structure, providing mechanical strength and protecting the image-receiving layer. The image-receiving layer is formed using a polymer system capable of receiving image-forming materials through dye diffusion thermal transfer.
</summary>

The text describes a method and device for detecting elementary particles, such as protons, ions, electrons, neutrons, or photons, in a detector. The method involves generating a charge pulse in the detector when a particle passes through it, converting each charge pulse into an electric signal, and amplifying the signal. The device includes a detector, at least one fast amplifier for amplifying individual signals, and a slow amplifier for integrating signals. The invention enables both the detection of individual particles and the integration of signals, without knowing in advance count or signal rates, and allows for the detection of small-size signals with a good signal/noise ratio. The method also proposes the use of a converter material for detecting uncharged particles and a fast detector material, such as diamond, for detecting particles over wide signal or count rates.

<summary>
This document describes an invention related to testing squirrel cage rotors of dynamoelectric machines, such as electric motors and generators, to obtain resistance, reactance, and effective electrical skew for identifying defects. The invention addresses the need for economical and reliable testing methods due to the infrequent occurrence of quality problems. Prior art methods include using stator cores, destructive testing, and non-destructive techniques with limitations. The invention provides a novel and improved method and apparatus for non-destructive testing of dynamoelectric machine rotors, including a test apparatus with a test head, excitation means, voltage sensing pick-up coil, skew sensing pick-up coil, current sensor, sample and hold circuit, phase locked loop, data acquisition and processing circuit, and data processor. The test head includes a set of primary windings, voltage pick-up coils, skew pick-up coils, and a core of magnetic material. The test apparatus controls rotation of the rotor, acquires data, and processes it to determine resistance, reactance, and effective skew values, as well as statistical information. The control processor determines pass/fail indications based on predetermined threshold values.
</summary>

The text describes a patent related to a fabrication method for producing plates or blanks of coated steel intended for welding and heat treatment to create parts with good mechanical strength, high impact resistance, and corrosion resistance. The method involves starting with hot- or cold-rolled steel plates coated with aluminum or aluminum alloy. Before heat treatment, the coating is heated to form a surface alloy by interdiffusion between the steel and the aluminum coating, preventing decarburization and oxidation during heat treatment.

To reduce vehicle weights, parts have been developed using steel blanks of different compositions or thicknesses continuously butt-welded together. These welded parts, known as "butt-welded blanks," are produced using laser beam welding, which allows for the variation of mechanical strength, pressability, and impact absorption properties within the parts.

The fabrication method described in the patent can be applied to butt-welded blanks by heating and pressing the blanks to form a surface alloy and then quenching them to create parts with thicknesses and intrinsic mechanical characteristics that vary, responding to local loading requirements.

However, this method faces difficulties when welding coated steel blanks, as a portion of the initial surface pre-coating is transferred into the molten area during welding and forms intermetallic areas. These intermetallic areas tend to be the site of onset of rupture under static or dynamic conditions, significantly reducing the overall deformability of the welded joints after heat treatment.

To address this issue, the present invention eliminates the source of these intermetallic areas by removing the initial surface metal coating in an area around the future welded joint. This prevents the formation of intermetallic areas during welding and subsequent alloying and austenizing heat treatment.

The invention also ensures good corrosion resistance by converting the precoat throughout its thickness into an intermetallic alloy compound during heat treatment, providing protection against corrosion and decarburization of the steel substrate. The method is economic, can be integrated into existing welding lines, and is compatible with subsequent pressing or heat treatment phases. The fabricated parts have satisfactory ductility and good corrosion resistance, with a total elongation across the welded joint greater than or equal to 4%.

<summary>
The text describes a system for compensating electromagnetic interfering fields using two real triaxial magnetic field sensors, three pairs of compensation coils, and one control unit. The control unit receives the output signals of the two real sensors, combines them to form the output signals of a virtual sensor, and processes these signals through independent control loops to generate control signals for the compensation coils. The system can compensate both homogeneous and inhomogeneous magnetic fields, and the control unit can be designed as a digital signal processor or a field programmable gate array. The virtual sensor output signals are used as inputs for the control loops, which can be broadband, selective concerning a frequency range, or selective concerning a frequency. The control loops transform the virtual input signals into modified signals, which are then used to calculate control signals for the compensation coils. The system can be used to compensate for inhomogeneous interfering fields, and the control unit can account for feedback effects between two compensation systems placed in close proximity.
</summary>

The control unit receives the output signals of the two real sensors, combines them to form the output signals of a virtual sensor, and processes these signals through independent control loops to generate control signals for the compensation coils. The system for compensating electromagnetic interfering fields uses two real triaxial magnetic field sensors to measure the interfering field, three pairs of compensation coils to generate the compensation field, and one control unit to process the sensor signals and generate the control signals for the compensation coils. The control unit receives the six output signals from the two real sensors

<summary>
The present invention relates to implementing a FIFO-type queue in a functional memory using a tree-shaped structure. In a functional memory, updates are made by copying the path from the root to the point of updating before making the update. A typical way of implementing a FIFO queue in overwrite memory environments using a double-ended list is ineffective in functional memories due to the need to copy the entire queue for each update. The invention reduces the amount of required copying by implementing and maintaining a queue using a tree-shaped structure in which additions and deletions are directed to specific nodes. Each update requires time and space that are logarithmically dependent on the length of the queue. The tree-shaped data structure is termed a tree, and nodes have a given maximum size. Additions are made to the first non-full node on the first edge of the tree, and deletions are made to a leaf node on the opposite edge. New nodes are created to keep leaf nodes at the same hierarchy level when necessary. The tree need not be updated with every addition or deletion, making updates faster and requiring less memory space. The queue can be inverted in constant time and space by changing the value of an identifier indicating which separate nodes constitute the beginning and end of the queue.
</summary>

<summary>
This text describes an invention for an improved apparatus for automatically spin checking driven disc assemblies. The apparatus includes a test enclosure with a stationary ring and a movable ring, a torque motor with a splined hub, and a servo motor with a ball screw shaft. The movable ring is slidably supported on the shaft and can be moved towards the stationary ring to frictionally engage the driven disc assembly. The torque motor is then energized to exert a predetermined torque on the driven disc assembly, and the movable ring is gradually moved away to reduce frictional force. When the frictional force decreases enough, the driven disc assembly begins to rotate under the torque motor's urging. The distance between the rings is measured before and after rotation, and the difference is compared to a standard value to determine if the driven disc assembly is excessively warped. The apparatus generates an external indication to the operator of the test results and operates automatically without manual involvement.
</summary>

An imaging device, such as a xerographic machine, uses a toner charged with tribo-electro-static charge for imaging operations. The toner concentration sensor measures the concentration of the toner by detecting the tribo charge, and a toner dispenser adjusts the supply based on the sensor output. If the imaging device is inactive for a long period, the tribo charge of the toner decreases, affecting image quality. Exemplary embodiments address this issue by determining periods of inactivity and charging the toner to a predetermined level based on the determined period.

The text describes a matrix display device that merges two images with different definitions for simultaneous display. The device applies algorithms to best preserve the definition of the higher definition image. The matrix display device consists of a controller and a matrix of pixels organized in a mosaic of identical arrangements, with each arrangement having pixels dedicated to displaying the first and second images. The merged image is produced via appropriate light intensity signals. The text provides examples of arrangements for monochrome and two-color images, and discusses the possibility of using different colors for the pixels dedicated to each image. The text also mentions the potential use of contrast reinforcement means to improve the merged image's appearance.

The present invention relates to a rotary magnetic head type apparatus that permits independent and precise regulation of bias currents supplied to plural MR heads mounted on a rotary drum in a simple structure. The apparatus uses a control signal generator on the stationary drum side and a decoder circuit and current supply circuit on the rotary drum side to control the operating currents of the magneto resistive heads, allowing for high-speed switching between plural MR and recording heads while maintaining their optimal operating points.

This text describes an invention for interfacing a speaker phone with a telephone network to enable hands-free automatic answering and communication. The invention includes a power source, selective switch means, a coupler for automatically connecting the telephone network to the speaker device, and a timer for limiting the duration of the interconnection. Two embodiments of the interfacing device are presented: one using an optocoupler and the other using a neon lamp and photocell. The system is designed to be portable, easily connectable to a telephone line, and versatile for various installation scenarios.

The text describes a mobile identification transmitter for activating a security system of a motor vehicle, which includes a payment element that can be brought into data communication with an electronic payment system. The housing of the identification transmitter has a receptacle into which the payment element is inserted, and a closure is arranged separately on the housing to protect and seal the receptacle when the payment element is removed. The payment element can be removed for various reasons, such as bringing the motor vehicle to a repair shop or for carrying out payment actions, and the user can carry out communication with the security system in both the normal and secure states of the identification transmitter. However, a payment action is blocked in the secure state because the payment element is no longer located in the receptacle of the housing. The closure effectively prevents disruptions to the connection between the payment element and the electronics of the identification transmitter and prevents moisture, dirt particles, etc. from penetrating into the interior of the housing.

<summary>
The text describes an invention related to determining the optimum value of feedback gains used in feedback control systems. Feedback control is commonly used to guide an automatic guidance vehicle (AGV) along a predetermined course. The correction amount is calculated based on the error detected between the actual and desired values, using proportional (P), integral (I), and differential (D) gains. The text discusses the importance of determining the proper values of these gains for achieving suitable stability, accuracy, and response in the feedback control system. The invention introduces evaluation functions for the individual P, I, and D gains, which can accurately evaluate their influence on the voltage curve and help determine their optimum values. The evaluation functions are shown to be effective in obtaining the optimum values of each gain irrespective of the settings of the other two gains. The text also discusses two methods for obtaining the ideal values of gains from evaluation function data: setting a fixed range with respect to the ideal value and selecting the value when it enters the optimum value range, or calculating the optimum values using function interpolation. A specific example is given for determining the optimum values of the P, I, and D gains for an AGV running along an oval course.
</summary>

The text describes an invention for determining the optimum value of feedback gains in feedback control systems. Feedback control is used to guide an automatic guidance vehicle (AGV) along a predetermined course, and the correction amount is calculated based on the error detected between the actual and desired values using proportional (P), integral (I), and differential (D) gains. The text emphasizes the importance of determining the proper values of these gains for achieving suitable stability, accuracy, and response. The invention introduces evaluation functions for the individual P, I, and D gains, which can accurately evaluate their influence on the voltage curve and help determine their optimum values. The evaluation functions are effective in obtaining the optimum values of each gain irrespective of the settings of the other two gains. An example is given for determining the optimum values of the P, I, and D gains for an AGV running along an oval course

The present invention relates to an improved collapsible light-shielding device for a screen. It consists of multiple annular strips that are concentrically nested and can slide over one another between a pushed-in and pushed-out position. The strips have a decreasing wall thickness, allowing the device to be folded around the screen and take up little space when not in use. Each strip has hooks or locking elements to ensure reliable folding and prevent separation. The invention also includes an adapter member with a flat attachment face, enabling the light-shielding device to be fixed to various types of monitors. The strips can be of solid design or bent plate material with integrated hooks or locking elements. The collapsible light-shielding device is inexpensive to produce, requires few parts, and can easily be fitted to a monitor.

<summary>
The text describes an invention related to zoom lenses for photographic and video cameras. The goal is to create a lens with a small F-number, high zoom ratio, and standard image angle at the wide angle end, while reducing the size of the entire lens system. The lens comprises a first lens unit for focusing, a second lens unit for magnification variation, a third lens unit for compensating for image plane shift, a fourth lens unit for making the diverging light beam almost afocal, and a fifth lens unit for image formation. The fourth and fifth lens units are designed to correct spherical aberration, astigmatism, and chromatic aberration. The invention also includes specific conditions for the radii of curvature, axial thicknesses, refractive indices, and Abbe numbers of the lenses to achieve high optical performance and reduce the physical length of the lens system. Four numerical examples are provided to illustrate the application of the invention.
</summary>

The text discusses an invention for zoom lenses that aim to provide a small F-number, high zoom ratio, and standard image angle at the wide angle end while reducing the size of the entire lens system. The lens consists of a first lens unit for focusing, a second lens unit for magnification variation, a third lens unit for compensating for image plane shift, a fourth lens unit for making the diverging light beam almost afocal, and a fifth lens unit for image formation. The fourth and fifth lens units are designed to correct spherical aberration, astigmatism, and chromatic aberration. The invention includes specific conditions for the radii of curvature, axial thicknesses, refractive indices, and Abbe numbers of the lenses to achieve high optical performance and reduce the physical length of the lens system. Four numerical examples are given to demonstrate the application of the invention.

This text introduces an invention for zoom lenses that offer a small F-number, high zoom ratio, and standard image angle at the wide angle end while minimizing the size of the entire lens system. The lens includes a first lens unit for focusing, a second lens unit for magnification variation, a third lens unit for compensating for image plane shift, a fourth lens unit for making the diverging light beam almost afocal, and a fifth lens unit for image formation. The fourth and fifth lens units are designed to correct spherical aberration, ast

<summary>
The present invention relates to automated speech technologies that automatically indicate to a speaker when their rate of speech is likely to exceed a rate that a listener can understand. This is accomplished by determining a speaking rate for the speaker and comparing it against a speaking rate threshold based on the listener's proficiency with the language being spoken. The speaker is informed to slow down through a sensory mechanism of a wearable computing device, such as a vibration, beep, or displayed message. The invention can be implemented as a method, device, or program and can be used in various communication scenarios, including face-to-face conversations, telephone calls, and web-based interactions. The device can also monitor the quality of a voice network connection and adjust the speaking rate accordingly.
</summary>

The text describes an invention for a cover plate device for wall-mounted electrical wiring devices, which aims to provide an improved design with no visible fasteners when installed. The device consists of a two-part system: an attachment plate and a cover plate. The attachment plate is attached to the wiring device using mounting screws, and it contains latching pawls and a tab. The cover plate is slightly larger than the attachment plate and the wiring device, and it has saw-tooth shaped racks on its end walls to engage the latching pawls of the attachment plate. The cover plate is separated from the attachment plate by using a small tool to press on the tab and pry off the cover plate. The design allows for easy installation and removal, and it can accommodate variations in wall flatness or evenness. The invention can be used for single or multiple wiring devices, and the number of racks, pawls, and tabs will depend on the number of wiring devices to be covered.

The present invention extends the viability of existing network devices by allowing them to support multimedia capabilities. It achieves this by routing incoming and outgoing calls to a blender associated with a multimedia server, which then initiates parallel voice and multimedia components. The blender maintains control over the signaling paths and merges them into a single session, allowing the multimedia server to control the bearer paths. The invention is compatible with various network systems and protocols, including SIP, and can be integrated with an Intelligent Network for basic call disposition handling. The processes can be rearranged to occur concurrently or in different orders as needed. The invention prolongs the life of existing network devices and enables seamless integration of multimedia services.

The present invention provides methods and systems for facilitating anonymous communication between a finder and owner of a lost or misplaced object, using a unique ID and a virtual locale to forward messages. The system allows for the registration of tags with contact information and the creation of open cases for communication between the parties.

<summary>
The invention describes a device for recording rapid processes using a TV camera with increased picture sequence frequency. It achieves this by using a cyclic counter and a sawtooth generator to control the vertical deviation and beam suppression of the camera. The counter supplies a pulse after scanning a certain number of lines, which is used to control the sawtooth generator and beam suppression circuit. The device allows for selectable picture sequence frequencies and line numbers, providing flexibility for different recording needs. The device can be implemented with minimal modifications to a conventional TV camera. The scanning of a reduced number of lines per picture results in a higher picture sequence frequency, although the spatial resolution in the vertical direction may be reduced. The video signals can be digitized and stored for analysis, with missing lines completed by repetition or interpolation. The counter's counting capacity can be adjusted to determine the optimal time and spatial resolution for recording different processes. The device can also be used to record IR, UV, or X-ray pictures.
</summary>

The present invention relates to a content synchronization framework for connected devices that allows for contextual synchronization over various communication network topologies. The framework includes a central reference point, client devices, and external partners, and allows for dynamic arbitrary attribute information to be used to compile bundle information for the requesting client. The framework also employs data compression and priority-based downloading to optimize communication bandwidth usage.

This text describes a home network system that allows network master nodes to transfer their administrative functions to network slave nodes, enabling the master nodes to enter power management modes and minimize energy consumption while maintaining network functionality. The system allows for selection of the most qualified slave node to become the new master node based on predetermined criteria.

The text describes a foil electron multiplier invention that uses a series of thin foils in an evacuated enclosure to amplify electrons or detect particles. The multiplier comprises a series of thin foils held by foil holders in an evacuated enclosure, with voltage applied to each foil to accelerate electrons and generate secondary electrons that continue to the next foil. The gain of the multiplier is maximized by optimizing the electron transmission through the foil, transmission through the support grid, and secondary electron emission yield. The invention offers advantages such as higher gain per multiplication stage, simpler fabrication process, lower cost, larger area coverage, and intrinsic rejection of ion feedback.

<summary>
The present invention relates to methods and software for estimating the age of a person from their image data. The inventors have discovered that using a contourlet appearance model (CAM) and classifying the subject face based on aging mechanisms can improve verification rates for image-based face age-estimation. The method involves extracting facial features from an image, mapping these features to age groups using differently calibrated mapping functions, and applying aging functions to generate the face age-estimation. The CAM algorithm is used to extract feature vectors from face images, which are then used as inputs to an age classifier and two aging functions. Support Vector Regression (SVR) is used to construct these functions and classifier. The goal is to build a hyper-plane as close to as many training points as possible while minimizing the sum of the distances from these points to the hyper-plane. The estimated age is provided in the form of a single age or age indicator with an optional confidence factor.
</summary>

The present invention is about methods and software for estimating the age of a person from their image data. The inventors have found that using a contourlet appearance model (CAM) and classifying the subject face based on aging mechanisms can improve verification rates for image-based face age-estimation. The method involves extracting facial features from an image, mapping these features to age groups using differently calibrated mapping functions, and applying aging functions to generate the face age-estimation.

The CAM algorithm is used to extract feature vectors from face images, which are then used as inputs to an age classifier and two aging functions. Support Vector Regression (SVR) is used to construct these functions and classifier. The goal is to build a hyper-plane as close to as many training points as possible while minimizing the sum of the distances from these points to the hyper-plane.

The estimated age is provided in the form of a single age or age indicator with an optional confidence factor. The method can be implemented using a computing system containing a set of instructions for implementing the aspects and methodologies of the present disclosure. The system includes a processor, memory, bus, input device, storage device, and output device.

The first image data received represents an image of one or more persons' faces for which ages are desired to be estimated. The image data is typically utilized in the form of a digital image contained in a suitable image

<summary>
The invention described herein is concerned with improving the ease and accuracy of locating and tracing concealed elongated conductive objects, such as pipes or cables, in the presence of an adjacent object. The prior art uses passive and active techniques for locating buried metallic objects, but both techniques have limitations when dealing with adjacent objects. The model MAC-51B Magnetic and Cable Locator is a selective active or passive system that can induce alternating currents in conductive objects and sense magnetic fields associated with those currents. However, when there are adjacent objects, the output signal can become distorted, making tracing difficult.

To address this issue, the invention employs a transmitter with a pair of antennae that induce distinguishable alternating currents in the adjacent objects. The receiver is movable relative to the transmitter and the objects and has means for sensing magnetic fields associated with the currents in each object. The output signal is dependent upon the sensing of both magnetic fields.

The transmitter is optimally positioned relative to the objects to produce two distinct output signal nulls over the respective objects. This allows for more accurate and easier tracing of one or both objects. The system is capable of producing output signal characteristics with distinct nulls and lobes, making it possible to locate and trace the desired object even in the presence of an adjacent object.

The transmitter may be initially positioned based on available information, but it can be moved to optimize further tracing operations. The system is capable of producing output signal characteristics with distinct nulls and lobes, making it possible to locate and trace the desired object even in the presence of an adjacent object.

The currents in the objects can be made distinguishable using various techniques, such as different carrier frequencies, amplitude modulation, or pulsing at different repetition rates. The receiver detects the envelope of the amplified signal and produces a beat frequency signal when both components are present.

The invention is especially useful in environments where the horizontal separation between the objects is related to the depth of the object to be located and traced. The field from the transmitter decreases by the inverse cube of the distance between the antennae and the object, reducing the inducement of currents from both antennae in the same object when the transmitter is properly positioned.
</summary>

The 3-D Phenomenoscope is a system that allows ordinary 2-dimensional motion pictures to be viewed with a 3-dimensional effect using Pulfrich glasses. The system consists of viewing glasses with right and left lenses, a digital sensor to capture images, a computer processor to process the images and identify synchronization events, and a means to control the darkness of the lenses based on the detected synchronization events. The glasses can take three states: clear-clear, clear-dark, and dark-clear, depending on the direction of lateral motion detected in the motion picture. The Glass Lens Controller Unit (GLCU) includes a digital sensor to take pictures, a processor to process the images, and a battery to power the system. The lens control algorithm uses an intensity edge map algorithm to detect lateral motion and determine the direction. The GLCU sends signals to independently control the darkness of the right and left lenses based on the detected synchronization events. The invention works with any type of motion picture media and allows older motion pictures to be viewed with a 3-dimensional effect.

The present invention relates to an image sensor with multiple imaging planes, including one on an edge surface. In the prior art, image sensors cannot be used to image in a plurality of planes, and charge carriers generated at the edges cannot be used to record information. The present invention overcomes these problems by providing a means for guiding charge carriers generated at the edges towards the charge collection and transfer means. The image sensor comprises a semiconductor substrate with a P-type bottom layer and an upper layer, and image sensor elements with photodiodes and buried-channel CCDs. A P+ layer is formed between the image sensors and the substrate edges to guide charge carriers back towards the middle of the substrate. The image sensor can be used to image in a plurality of planes, allowing for various image formats such as simultaneous imaging of opposing surfaces or surface imaging of passageways. The present invention can be easily incorporated into known image sensors using compatible processing techniques.

<summary>
The present invention is a system for reducing or eliminating undersea optical repeaters in a trunk and branch ring network by replacing repeaters with remotely pumped optical amplifiers and supplying energy to those amplifiers over the same branch cables. The system includes an optical fiber cable trunk in ring topology with telecommunications hubs and branching units, each with a branch fiber optic cable and a cable station. The branch fiber optic cable is used to transmit both communications signals and optical energy to remotely located optical amplifiers. The hub assembly also includes a light emitting power source and can remotely supply energy to the optical amplifiers. The trunk and branch structure with ring geometry provides strong survivability features, allowing for full connectivity even with a single trunk cut or multiple branch cuts. The use of remotely pumped optical amplifiers reduces the number of undersea repeaters required and lowers capital and operating costs.
</summary>

The present invention is a system for reducing or eliminating undersea optical repeaters in a trunk and branch ring network by replacing repeaters with remotely pumped optical amplifiers and supplying energy to those amplifiers over the same branch cables. The system includes an optical fiber cable trunk in ring topology with one or more telecommunications hubs serially interconnected, each hub being an access point to the trunk by a major switching office. Also coupled serially along the optical fiber cable trunk are one or more branching units, which are optical coupling devices that allow for convenient add/drop points for telecommunications traffic.

Connected to each branching unit is a branch fiber optic cable, which in turn is optically coupled at its other end to a cable station. A cable station accesses one or more of the signal wavelengths transported along the cable trunk and is bilateral in that communications signals are both sent to the cable trunk and retrieved from the cable trunk at this point.

The present invention utilizes the branch fiber optic cable, along which communications signals are transmitted and received, to further unidirectionally transmit optical energy at a wavelength other than that of signal wavelength. The optical energy is used as a power source for an optical amplifier, which is located in the branch fiber optic cable, the optical fiber cable trunk, or the branching unit. Signal amplification is thereby provided without the use of conventional optical repeaters.

A similar arrangement is

This document describes an electronic communications terminal for Internet/network telephony that uses wireless near field communication to establish a connection to a network or the Internet. The terminal converts sound into digital format, handles communication using standardized Internet/network protocols, and can communicate additional information and data with the connecting unit. The system includes a portable communications terminal, a connecting unit, and a service server, allowing for centralized handling and control of connections between users and providing additional services.

<summary>
The present invention relates to a method and apparatus for dicing semiconductor wafers using pressure instead of a wafer saw. The process involves forming trenches along scribe lines on the wafer and applying mechanical pressure to singulate the individual die. The apparatus includes a pad for supporting the wafer and a positioning member to position it. A pressure mechanism applies the pressure to singulate the die.

A semiconductor wafer includes die fabricated on its surface, separated by horizontal and vertical scribe lines. The wafer undergoes various processing steps, including applying a photo resist layer, patterning it to form openings over the scribe lines, etching the wafer to form trenches along the scribe lines, and removing the photo resist layer. An optional back-grinding step reduces the wafer's thickness.

A layer of adhesive tape is applied to the back surface of the wafer, and it is placed on a soft pad with its active surface down. Mechanical pressure is applied to the back surface to cause a clean break along the trenches, singulating the dice. A ring is used to hold the wafer in place during singulation.

The process can be used for wafers of any size or type of die, and the trenches can be formed by partially cutting the wafer with a wafer saw or on the bottom surface. The invention should not be limited to the details given but defined by the appended claims and their full scope of equivalents.
</summary>

The text describes a new subminiature lamp assembly that utilizes a high temperature polymeric seal support to surround and compress the glass envelope, providing a liquid-tight seal and eliminating the need for adhesives. The polymeric seal support is made of a fluoroelastomer material, which is chemically resistant and able to withstand high temperatures. The seal support extends downward and over the exterior of the abbreviated height one piece conductive base, encapsulating the glass envelope and making a static radial seal with the straight sidewall of the glass envelope. The elimination of adhesives allows for closer tolerance centering of the subminiature lamp to the axis of the abbreviated height one piece conductive base, reducing the potential for poor seals. The use of a pourable potting material underneath the glass envelope further protects the lamp and provides additional insulation. The invention can be applied to any situation where insulation, high heat degradation resistance, solvent and chemical resistance, and effective sealing are required.

The text describes a method for realizing a Generalized Decision Feedback Equalizer (GDFE) Precoder for multi-user (MU) MIMO systems, which significantly reduces computational cost while maintaining system capacity. The method relaxes the requirement for knowledge of the covariance matrix (S zz ) corresponding to "Least Favorable Noise," and provides a uniform framework for realizing a GDFE Precoder. The described implementation achieves significant improvement in computational cost over conventional GDFE Precoders. The text also includes numerical examples illustrating the computation of various matrices involved in the design of GDFE Precoders using different methods. The first example uses equation (12) to compute the matrix C, the second example uses equation (22) when S zz is unknown, and the third example uses equation (26) for a non-square channel matrix H. The text also mentions the MAC/BC duality and the concept of least favorable noise.

The text describes an electroluminescent display panel invention that can display different colors without using an intermediate electrode. The panel is composed of various layers laminated on a glass substrate, including first and second electrode layers, insulation layers, and luminescent layers. The first luminescent layer emits green light, while the second luminescent layer, which overlaps the first layer, emits orange light and forms a single layer portion and a double layer portion. The single layer portion emits green light at a low voltage, while the double layer portion emits lemon light at a high voltage. The panel can be used as an automobile instrument panel, displaying green light at night and lemon light during the day for high luminance and driver comfort.

The text describes an invention that uses a recessed mask structure to prevent high electrical fields at intersections in very small semiconductor devices, reducing leakage and electrical breakdown. The mask is positioned below the surface to be planarized, away from high electric field locations, and where the dielectric between conductors is undisturbed. This results in a lower effective dielectric constant and reduced lateral leakage current between adjacent metal lines. The invention is particularly useful in damascene type device structures and is effective in minimizing damage to conductive liners during processing.

The present invention relates to a method for optimizing the visual impact of an advertising clip inserted into a video sequence. It proposes accounting for the regions of interest of the video sequence and the advertising clip to ensure continuity between them. The method involves generating salience maps for the video sequence and each advertising clip, determining their similarity, and selecting the clip with the highest degree of similarity. The insertion point can be predefined or automatically detected at a shot change. The degree of similarity can be determined using correlation coefficients or Kullback-Leibler divergence. The method can also be implemented using a device for processing pictures.

The text describes an invention related to a heat-dissipating fan and its housing. The objective is to increase the intake airflow rate without modifying the assembling conditions and to enhance the heat-dissipating efficiency. The housing includes an outer frame with a passage for guiding air streams, and an sidewall of the passage extends radially outwards to enlarge the intake area. The sidewall can extend symmetrically with respect to the central and longitudinal axes of the passage and beyond the peripheral edge of the outer frame.
