The Welsh Government discussed the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on education in Wales during an evidence session with Minister Kirsty Williams, Director Steve Davies, Group Director Huw Morris, and Chief Scientific Adviser Rob Orford. The Minister outlined plans to support vulnerable children and ensure continuity of learning during school closures, including the use of digital tools and the provision of emergency food support. The government is also working on legislation to provide Welsh Ministers with temporary powers to close schools and direct resources as needed.

The Welsh Government, led by Education Minister Kirsty Williams, held an evidence session with the Children, Young People and Education Committee regarding the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on education in Wales. The session covered the government's response to the crisis, including the closure of schools and the implementation of distance learning, as well as plans for supporting vulnerable learners and continuing education during the pandemic.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee held an evidence session with the Welsh Government regarding the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on education in Wales. Kirsty Williams, Minister for Education, provided an opening statement, outlining the decision to close schools and the new purpose of schools to support vulnerable children and ensure continuity of learning. Dawn Bowden asked about the practicalities of implementing the new purpose, including staffing and identifying vulnerable children. Steve Davies explained that schools will be used to support children of key workers and provide emergency responses for free school meals and additional learning needs. The Minister confirmed that all maintained schools already have access to digital tools for distance learning. Yesterday, the Minister announced that summer exams would not be proceeding, and learners would be awarded grades based on a range of information. The Minister thanked everyone for their hard work and expressed the need to continue working together to face the challenges posed by the coronavirus.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a virtual meeting to discuss the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales. The meeting was broadcast live on Senedd.tv with all participants joining via video conference. The Minister for Education, Kirsty Williams AM, and her officials attended to provide evidence. The Minister expressed gratitude to everyone working to keep schools open and helping children learn at home. She outlined the challenges facing the education system due to the pandemic and the importance of protecting the health and well-being of children and staff. Hefin David asked about the timeline for schools reopening and the Minister clarified that it would not be imminent and would depend on advice from the chief medical officer and scientific officer. The Minister also mentioned the importance of clear communication to parents and staff and the need to consider which groups of children should return to school first. The Minister confirmed that the principles for schools also apply to further education and universities, and they are working with representatives of the HE sector to include them in the planning process. Sian Gwenllian questioned the wisdom of starting to relax restrictions when testing hasn't been sufficiently developed and asked if it conveyed a mixed message. The Minister clarified that they are not relaxing any issues around schools at present and that a return to normal is not imminent. Suzy Davies asked about managing school absences and the Minister confirmed that they will seek to reduce burdens on schools by suspending performance measures and removing the requirement for literacy and numeracy testing. Dawn Bowden asked about the arrangements for facilitating more vulnerable children to attend school hubs and the Minister confirmed that they are working across Government departments to ensure that children and young people's needs are catered for and that they have been in touch with local authorities to make sure that children and families are receiving support.

Kirsty Williams AM, the Welsh Minister for Education, addressed the Children, Young People and Education Committee regarding the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales. She expressed gratitude to all those involved in keeping schools open and supporting children's learning during the crisis. Williams outlined five principles to guide decisions about when schools will reopen, emphasizing the importance of considering the safety and well-being of children and staff, communicating clearly with parents and staff, and planning for the operational challenges of reopening schools. She acknowledged that a return to normal education is not imminent and that testing, tracing, and quarantine measures will be crucial in the next phase. Williams also discussed the challenges of supporting vulnerable children and those with additional learning needs, as well as the importance of mental health support during the crisis. She announced that PS1.25 million would be made available for school counselling services and that officials are working with local authorities to ensure that all children have access to the hardware and connectivity they need for remote learning. Williams also addressed concerns about examinations and the awarding of grades to A-level and GCSE students, stating that teachers will be asked to submit their professional judgment about students' grades and that these will be moderated to ensure fairness and maintain the integrity of the qualifications system. She also mentioned that unconditional offers for university entry remain in place until May 1st and that discussions are ongoing about extending this moratorium. Williams confirmed that student support payments will not be affected by students returning home during the crisis and that maintenance loans will continue to be paid during the summer holiday period. She also acknowledged the challenges facing universities and expressed a desire to support students during this difficult time. The committee then resolved to meet in private for the remainder of the meeting.

The Welsh Government, led by Education Minister Kirsty Williams, discussed the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on education in Wales during an evidence session before the Children, Young People and Education Committee. They outlined plans to keep schools open for vulnerable children, key workers, and to ensure continuity of learning, including the use of digital tools and the cancellation of summer exams.

The Welsh Government, led by Education Minister Kirsty Williams, held an evidence session with the Children, Young People and Education Committee regarding the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on education in Wales. The Minister expressed her concern for the safety and well-being of staff and pupils while ensuring continuity of education. Schools will close for statutory education provision but will have a new purpose, including supporting vulnerable children and ensuring continuity of learning. The decision to cancel summer exams was made due to public health concerns, and students will be awarded grades based on a range of information. The Minister acknowledged the challenges faced by universities and colleges in delivering education during the pandemic and assured that student maintenance payments will continue as normal. The Welsh Government is also considering providing additional support for students, particularly those with additional learning needs, and is in discussions with local authorities and youth services to maintain services for vulnerable children.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a virtual meeting to discuss the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales. Minister Kirsty Williams, Steve Davies, director of the education directorate, and Huw Morris, group director, skills, higher education and lifelong learning, attended the session. She outlined the challenges facing the education system due to the pandemic and the importance of prioritizing children's health and well-being.

In response to a question from Hefin David, the Minister clarified that schools will reopen when it is safe to do so and when advised by the chief medical officer and chief scientific officer. She emphasized that a return to normal is not imminent and that planning and communication with parents and staff are crucial. The Minister also acknowledged the importance of testing and working with international partners to gather best practices.

Suzy Davies asked about the safety of school staff and children in hubs, to which the Minister responded that there have been 15 teachers tested for COVID-19, with two positive results. She emphasized the importance of following guidelines and reporting incidents to ensure the smooth operation of hubs.

Dawn Bowden asked about the support for vulnerable children and the potential for relaxing lockdown rules for those with special educational needs. The Minister acknowledged the challenges and the importance of cross-government collaboration, as well as the need for ongoing contact and support for families.

Sian Gwenllian questioned the wisdom of starting to relax restrictions when testing is not yet sufficiently developed and asked about the impact on further education and universities. The Minister clarified that the principles apply to both schools and FE colleges, and that they are working with representatives of the HE sector to include them in the planning process.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a virtual meeting to discuss the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales. Minister Kirsty Williams, Steve Davies, and Huw Morris attended to provide evidence. The Minister expressed gratitude to those keeping schools open and helping children learn at home. She acknowledged the challenges facing education due to the pandemic and the importance of protecting children's health and well-being. Hefin David asked about the timeline for schools reopening, and the Minister stated that it would not be imminent and would depend on advice from medical and scientific advisers. Suzy Davies asked about the number of children attending school hubs and the safety measures in place. The Minister stated that 518 school hubs were open each day, with approximately 5.6% of the teaching population working in those hubs. About 85% of the children attending were the children of key workers, and 600 vulnerable children were attending daily. The Minister acknowledged the importance of testing in dealing with the crisis and the need for clear communication with parents and staff. Dawn Bowden asked about support for vulnerable children and the potential for relaxation of lockdown rules for those with special educational needs. The Minister stated that local authorities were working to ensure that vulnerable children were receiving support and that schools were in contact with families. She also acknowledged the challenges for children with additional learning needs and the need for flexibility in supporting them. The Minister also discussed the importance of mental health support for children and the allocation of PS1.25 million for school counselling services. The committee also discussed the potential for the attainment gap between disadvantaged pupils and their more affluent peers due to varying access to digital resources. The Minister acknowledged the importance of ensuring equal access to learning and the need to work closely with local authorities to provide hardware and connectivity to students in need.

The Children, Young People and Education Committee held a scrutiny session on the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill. Witnesses included Sally Jenkins from the Association of Directors of Social Services, Alastair Birch from the Association of Directors of Education Wales, and Councillor Huw David from the Welsh Local Government Association. The group discussed their general support for the Bill and why they believe the current law is ineffective or unclear. They emphasized the importance of upholding the rights of the child and the need for clarity in legislation. The witnesses also discussed the potential unintended consequences of the Bill, including increased awareness of the UNCRC and potential changes to social services interaction with parents. They acknowledged the need for resources and support for families and preventative services. The committee asked about the practical ways in which social services' interaction with parents will change and the potential impact on emergency and out-of-hours local authority services. The witnesses expressed confidence that teachers and other educational professionals will be clear about how to support the implementation of the Bill and that the duty to report significant harm will remain. The group also discussed the importance of awareness raising and who should be responsible for it. The committee raised concerns about the costs of implementing the Bill and the need for transparency about those costs. The witnesses agreed to work with Welsh Government to identify and quantify those costs as part of the implementation phase.
